columns.text: In this exercise, we are to determine the sustainable growth rate of the company.

## Sustainable Growth Rate
\
The sustainable growth rate is referred to as the maximum rate of growth attainable by the company without the need for external equity financing and at the same time, maintaining the debt-to-equity at a constant ratio.

The sustainable growth rate is the maximum rate of growth that a company would attain which requires the firm not to increase the company equity. While the ROE is the ratio of the net income and the equity.
\
Therefore, the sustainable growth rate is directly proportional to the ROE indicating that as the ROE increases, the sustainable growth rate increases and as the ROE decreases, the sustainable growth rate decreases as well.

## Profit Margin
\
Profit margin is the ratio to which the company generates profit from its revenue.
\
Profit margin is considered as a determinant of growth since an increase in this ratio will consequently increase the company's ability to generate profit that is used to fund the internal operations of the firm, thus increasing the sustainable growth of the company.
\
The profit margin is computed as follows:
 
$$\text{Profit Margin}=\frac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Sales}}$$

## Capital Intensity Ratio
\
The capital intensity ratio is referred to as the ratio of the assets that generate the sales of the operations of the company.
\
The capital intensity ratio is computed as follows:
 
$$\text{Capital Intensity Ratio}=\frac{\text{Total Assets}}{\text{Sales}}$$

## Debt-to-Equity Ratio
\
The debt-to-equity ratio is referred to as the ratio of the liabilities and equity that is used to finance the operations of the company.
\
The debt-to-equity ratio is computed as follows:
 
$$\text{Debt-to-Equity Ratio}=\frac{\text{Total Liabilities}}{\text{Total Equity}}$$
**Now, let us determine the sustainable growth of the company using the aforementioned ratios.**

Now, let us determine the amount of the Sales account using the following given:
 
 <center>

|Given||
|:--|--:|
|Profit Margin of the Company|7.3\%|
|Net Income|\$73,000|
 

Thus, using the profit margin formula, the amount of sales is calculated as follows:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Profit Margin}&=\frac{\text{Net Income}}{\text{Sales}}\\[12pt]
7.3\%&=\frac{\$73,000}{\text{Sales}}\\[12pt]
7.3\%\times\text{Sales}&={\$73,000}\\[12pt]
\frac{7.3\%\times\text{Sales}}{7.3\%}&=\frac{\$73,000}{7.3\%}\\[12pt]
\text{Sales}&=\boxed{\$1,000,000}\\
\end{aligned}$$
 ;
**The sales of the company amounts to \$1,000,000.**

Now, let us determine the amount of the asset account using the following given:
 
 <center>

|Given||
|:--|--:|
|Capital Intensity Ratio|0.80|
|Sales (Calculated Amount)|\$1,000,000|
 

Thus, using the capital intensity formula, the amount of total assets is calculated as follows:
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Capital Intensity Ratio}&=\frac{\text{Total Assets}}{\text{Sales}}\\[12pt]
0.80&=\frac{\text{Total Assets}}{\text{\$1,000,000}}\\[12pt]
\text{Total Assets}&=0.80\times\text{\$1,000,000}\\[12pt]
&=\boxed{\$800,000}\\
\end{aligned}$$
 ;
**The assets of the company amounts to \$800,000.**

Based on the computations in the preceding steps, we can now use the computed amounts to determine the return on equity using the DuPont Equation of Profit Margin, Asset Turnover, and Equity Multiplier.

To compute the Equity Multiplier:
$$\text{Equity Multiplier}=\frac{\text{Assets}}{\text{Total Equity}}$$
 
Since the total equity is not given, the following formula is used:
$$\text{Equity Multiplier}=\text{Debt-to-Equity Ratio}+1$$

We can also determine the return on equity without the need for the computation of the sales and asset amounts. The formula is as follows:
$$\begin{aligned}\text{Return on Equity}&=\text{Profit Margin}\times\frac{1}{\text{Capital Intensity Ratio}}\\[10pt]
&\times(1+\text{Debt-to-Equity Ratio})\\
\end{aligned}$$
 
*The total assets turnover is the reciprocal of the capital intensity ratio.*

To compute the return on equity:
 
$$\begin{aligned}\text{Return on Equity}&=\text{Profit Margin}\times\frac{1}{\text{Capital Intensity Ratio}}\\[10pt]
&\times(1+\text{Debt-to-Equity Ratio})\\[12pt]
&=\text{7.3\%}\times\frac{1}{\text{0.80}}\times(1+\text{0.95})\\[12pt]
&=\text{7.3\%}\times1.25\times1.95\\[12pt]
&=\boxed{0.18}\\
\end{aligned}$$
 
**The return on equity is 0.1779.**

Now, let us compute the sustainable growth rate:
 
$$\begin{aligned}
\text{Sustainable Growth Rate}&=\frac{\text{ROE} \times b}{1-\text{ROE}\times b}\times 100\\[12pt]
&=\frac{0.1779\times 67\%}{1-0.1779\times 67\%}\times 100\\[12pt]
&=\frac{0.1192}{1-0.1192}\times 100\\[12pt]
&=\frac{0.1192}{0.8808}\times 100\\[12pt]
&={0.1353}\times 100\\[12pt]
&=\boxed{13.53\%}\\
\end{aligned}$$
Where:
ROE= Return on Equity
*b*= Retention Ratio

 
**The sustainable growth rate of the company is 13.53\%.**
The problem will require us to compute the sustainable growth rate of  Kaleb's Heavy Equipment.

### Let's first provide the given data.

* Profit margin of 7.3%.
* Capital intensity ratio of 0.80.
* Debt-equity ratio of 0.95.
* Net Income of $73,000.00.
* Declared dividends of $24,000.00.

## Requirement.

### Compute the sustainable growth rate.

Sustainable growth is calculated with a retention ratio and returns on equity.

### Compute the retention ratio.

The retention ratio is the percentage share of the retained earnings added to the equity section. We will first compute the payout ratio in the absence of the retained earnings to compute the retention ratio.

### Compute the payout ratio.

The payout ratio is the percentage share of the declared dividends from the net income.

The formula is as follows.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Payout Ratio}&= \dfrac{ \text{Declared Dividends}}{\text{Net Income}}\\[15pt]
&=\dfrac{\$24,000.00}{\$73,000.00}\\[15pt]

&= 0.3288 \times 100\\[15pt]

&= \boxed{\textbf{32.88\%}}

\end{aligned}
$$

### Now that the payout ratio is available, we can compute the retention ratio.

The retention ratio plus payout ratio is equal to one. To compute the retention ratio, we will deduct the payout ratio to 1. The payout ratio of 32.88% is converted to the decimal value of 0.3288.

The formula is as follows.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Retention Ratio}&= 1 - \text{Payout Ratio}\\[15pt]

&= 1 - 0.3288\\[15pt]

&= 0.6712 \times 100\\[15pt]

&= \boxed{\textbf{67.12\%}}

\end{aligned}
$$


Therefore, the retention ratio is **67.12%**.

### Compute the sales.

The given in the problem is the profit margin. From the profit margin, we can derive the calculation of sales.

The formula for computing profit margin is as follows.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Profit Margin}&= \dfrac{ \text{Net Income}}{\text{Sales}}\\[15pt]

\end{aligned}
$$

### Derive the calculation of sales from the profit margin.

Computation of sales can be derived from the formula of profit margin.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Sales}&= \dfrac{ \text{Net Income}}{\text{Profit Margin}}\\[15pt]

\end{aligned}
$$

### Compute the assets of the company.

The given in the problem is the capital intensity ratio. From the capital intensity ratio, we can derive the calculation of the total assets.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Capital Intensity}&= \dfrac{ \text{Total Assets}}{\text{Sales}}\\[15pt]

\end{aligned}
$$

### Compute the return on equity.

The return on equity can be calculated using the DuPont equation of Return on Equity. The DuPont Equation includes the profit margin, asset turnover, and equity multiplier.

### Compute the sustainable growth rate.

Now that the return on equity and the retention ratio is available, we can compute the sustainable growth rate.

The formula and calculation are as follows.

$$
\begin{aligned}
\textbf{Sustainable Growth Rate}&= \dfrac{\text{ROE $\times$ b}}{\text{1 - ROE $\times$ b}}\\[15pt]
&= \dfrac{17.79\% \times 67.12\%}{1 - 17.79\% \times 67.12\%}\\[15pt]
&= \dfrac{0.1194}{1 - 0.1194}\\[15pt]
&= \dfrac{0.1194}{0.8806}\\[15pt]
&= 0.1356 \times 100\\[15pt]
&= \boxed{\textbf{13.56\%}}
\end{aligned}
$$


Therefore, the sustainable growth rate is **13.56%**.
